conclusion: Analyze the motion of particles A and B based on their velocity-time graph.
The graph shows the velocity of each particle as a function of time.
Identify the initial conditions for both particles. Both particles start from rest at the same time, so their initial velocity v_0 is the same.
Determine the acceleration for each particle. Since both particles start from rest, their initial acceleration is a = v_0/t_0.
Analyze the deceleration phase. During the deceleration phase, the velocity decreases, and the acceleration becomes negative.
For particle A, the deceleration phase occurs between 3t_0 and 4t_0.
For particle B, the deceleration phase occurs between 5t_0 and 6t_0.
Calculate the magnitudes of the accelerations for A and B during their deceleration phases.
For particle A, the acceleration a_A = v_0/t_0.
For particle B, the acceleration a_B = -v_0/t_0.
Calculate the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations. Since a_A = v_0/t_0 and a_B = -v_0/t_0, the ratio of their magnitudes is a_A/a_B = 1.
Since the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations is 1, the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1.
The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1.
